text: - Hi, I'm Danilo.

I'm part of the developer
relations team in AWS.
Hi Bob.

Thanks for spending
some time with us today.
- Yeah, hi Danilo.

- Can you introduce
yourself and, and Cazoo?
- Sure, so I'm Bob Gregory.
I used to be the chief architect at Cazoo.
I'm now an engineering coach.
Cazoo is an online car retailer in the UK.
- And what does Cazoo do differently

from other companies that,
that sell cars online?

- So I think Cazoo was
one of the first movers

in kind of the current wave
of online car retailers.

So I think other people
had tried it before
but maybe the market wasn't quite ready.
So when Cazoo launched,

really there were
aggregators like Autotrader,

but there wasn't anyone who
was really doing e-commerce

for cars, that wasn't
really a market segment.

And actually kind of
the used car market was

really the last retail
sector that hadn't yet
made that online transition.
So, Cazoo was lucky to be

in the right time, at
the right place I think.
- So I can buy a car online,

and how much does it take to
have it delivered at my home?
- It's 72 hours is the shortest time.
- That's amazing.
So how did you start and grow so quickly
from an infrastructure point of view?
- I mean infrastructural, we've been

on serverless technology
since day one, right?
So actually it's quite easy to scale.
I don't have to scale it.

I think the, most of the
challenges we had were around

how do you decompose this kind
of very complex domain model.

Turns out the cars are very
complex product to sell.
They have lots of legal requirements
around like tax and MOT.

There's this whole complex
registration thing.
There's vehicle finance
which is like secured asset finance.

All of these things are
very complex domains.

So actually most of the
complexity at Cazoo in terms

of scaling has been how do
we take this very large set

of complex domain problems
and partition them

amongst teams and grow the
team very quickly rather

than the infrastructure,
which was thanks to you,
very, very easy.
- And how, how did you end up with

this idea of using a
serverless architecture?

- From my perspective, I
came into Cazoo very early

and I knew I wanted to go
serverless from day one.

I'd built a platform service
internally, a previous job
which was also an e-commerce company.
And that took us about five years

of kind of iteration to kind
of experiment with technology
see what worked and what didn't.
And it was great, but it was an awful lot

of work to kind of get the
ops team and the engineers

to the point where they
were comfortable working
with those technologies
and we could maintain and in production.
Serverless for us meant we could
skip to that end goal, right?

Where you want elastic
scale, you want resilience
you want ease of use.
Those things came out of the box
for us with AWS Lambda,
and the kind of the associated ecosystem,

rather than us having
to build it in house.
- So as you are growing so fast
I think also that the team is growing.

So how do you onboard
new software developers?

- So we actually run a
thing we call Tech Academy

and we have like a boot
camp process where,
now this is only just really started,
but as a new engineer at Cazoo,
you will start on a given start date along

with a cohort of other people
who are starting on that date.

And you'll go through like
a week long training scheme

with those other engineers
where we introduce you
to the domain model.
We talk about our ways of working.
So you know, we have a particular flavor
of agile that we use.
We use kind of collaborative play,

like event storming or
domain storytelling.
We do that kind of thing with them.

But part of that tech
academy is we do a serverless
workshop where engineers build
and deploy their first Lambda functions
in the space of an afternoon,

and then learn how to use
observability tools to look
at them in production, that kind of thing.

- So would you like to share
what you're working next?
- In terms of technology,

really we are now kind of
into an optimization phase.
So we've proven we can sell cars online,
and that people will buy them,
that we can move them around.

Next we want to kind
of optimize every part
of that journey to drive margin.
So we'll be looking at

kind of your machine
learning, image Rekognition

techniques to improve
operational efficiency.
That's really where we're going next.

- Thank you so much Bob, that's
been really interesting talk
and yeah, let's chat again next time.
- I look forward to it.
